author: -Bearaxe-
body:
I think...

TSLA, ENPH, SEDG and the solar and energy storage sector in general will feed on big oil dysfunction and current social sentiment moving in their favor.

Starlink IPO will be huge. Global high speed wifi service. Has a detailed YouTube video

Whichever mining company gets the opportunity to expand their tech to push asteroid mining resources via partnership with spacex or [space race winner]. Jeff Bezos has already created a sol system shipping infrastructure plan to mine the Kuiper belt. 

Work from home enterprises will gain steam. MSFT, ZM 

SQ is likely to do very well attempting to keep small businesses and contractors in the game with fluid mobile commerce.

Drone services. Specifically in CAD mapping and in tandem with a.i., drone software will replace many jobs. I'm a bridge inspector and already they are used often, with many of us realizing we won't have field work in the next few years. Drones are just too cheap, eliminating high insurance premiums and creating greater proof of work/protection against negligence claims.

Virtual and augmented reality will push into daily routines with further adoption of wearable technology and advancement of micro sensors. I don't know who is in the lead in this sector, but Neuralink scares the poo outta me. Like that's an idea straight out of the book of revalation... also has a detailed YouTube video if you want to see legit mind reading brain chips.

These are things I just see as inevitable outcomes in a further corporatized world that is constantly seeking to hedge against liability and produce greater efficiency from an increasingly distracted workforce. The sci-fi channel has arrived.

author: 4121Laurel
body:
No although you’re very invested in technology
Which isn’t a bad thing.  
- AAPL is great, their market value will always go back to what it was even if they don’t release the new iPhone. Don’t be afraid of a drop just average costs if it drops dramatically. 

- Adobe should do well with this stay at home. School is requiring the use as well as businesses from home. 

- Amazon is essentially showing its untouchable currently. I’m large into amazon as well. 

- Disney is another powerhouse that you’ll never need to worry about. The lost revenues over the following 8 months could cause a dramatic drop, in this scenario don’t panic and average your cost. 

- Enph - energy, I’m not familiar with this company. 

- Facebook is another powerhouse good pick. 

- Google - Great pick. 

- MasterCard is also a good pick, hold this. Average if it comes down to although you shouldn’t have to they trade rather high. If you’re at a major loss with their recent decline. Average in the next 3 months when there’s a better understanding how financials will deal with crisis. (You shouldn’t need to) 

- Microsoft - I love microsoft. They are on a tear currently. Teams daily usage is up 12 million users in the last month, this is major. Their competition is “work” slack technologies who I am also Long. 

- Netflix has been great good pick. 

- Nike is a great pick. I could expand but they’ve always done well. Constant increase throughout the life of their stock. 

- Nvidia is a powerhouse as well. Great pick. 

- Starbucks is great. I haven’t followed them through the virus but they’re a strong company large capital, their profits are also great. Good pick. 

- Square I like square a lot. Square has major potential in different avenues. Cash app, lending (they just got approved to lend during this time). Prior to the virus square was on a tear. I’m long on this I got in early and am very big on square. 

If you’re interested in diversification:

All that being said you really are big into tech, I would suggest diversification. 

“Oxy” - occidental petroleum is a good long term stock. They’re trading extremely low currently due to oil wars, corona virus, issues on the board and the purchase of anadarko. (This scares a lot of investors but you seem to want long term investments) it’s a steal at 15$ a share. 

- Johnson and Johnson is a powerhouse. 

- Jet blue & Delta - long term great investments. Short term extremely risky. 

- Walmart: trading high but they’re only going to go even higher when this is over. 

- AT&T and Verizon: AT&T trades fairly low with a large dividend. GREAT LONG TERM. Verizon has been extremely strong throughout the years.  

- Ford on the long term has a lot of upside trading around half of its average price. Ford pays dividend and  history has proven America will never let ford fail. 

- USO is an ETF that tracks United States Oil, It’s trading extremely low, no reason not to diversify with this. ( The oil war between Saudi and Russia is coming to an end, this should do well in the long term) 

- Have you put any though into mutual funds to also diversify ? A good managed funds typically has large returns and low risk. 

Reach out to me if you’d like.

author: HomieNR
body:
I'm not familiar with dividend drips. (Disclaimer: I am by no means professional)  in this period I focus on buying strong companies who also pay a decent dividend. For example i have been buying BMY and ABBV on a 30% discount (3.5% and 5.5% dividend respectively). But also stocks with a lot of growth potential like ENPH and LRCX. I am not done buying so whenever they get cheaper I spill in some more. These are not recommendations but stocks I have found potential in. 

Good thing about dividend stocks is that they tend to have a more stable price and not swing down that much.

author: Firmest_Midget
body:
Look into renewable energy stocks. Business is still booming, and going only up for a long time. NEE, ENPH, and SEDG for example are all hugely depressed and ready to pop when things start to clear up.  

Source: Work office job for renewable energy broker.  

NEE $340c 1/21/21, ENPH $60c 1/21/21

author: HouseOfSauce
body: Dear diary, bought ENPH puts earlier this morning. Will likely cash out before end of day. Do not wish to anger Jpow over Easter weekend. Amen.

author: Firmest_Midget
body:
What tickers do you think are shitty and insolvent? I'm holding puts dated between july and october this year for OXY, USO, HYG, and COOP right now. Open to others.  

Also, I'm hella bullish on the renewable energy sector. NEE, SEDG, and ENPH for example are all depressed with the general market right now, but still have booming business and high growth expectations. I just picked up calls this week dated 2021 for all three. I work for a renewable energy broker, and all the market talk in my group is good news. This oil price conflict is hugely beneficial to renewables, for example.

author: RonnieWhatley

author: spald01
body:
I'm watching ENPH, but their gains over the last year were likely heavily propped up by the bull run.  They went from a penny stock to nearly 10x that value over the year just because they stopped losing money each quarter.  Also, with oil way down and people having less money to spend, I don't see as many solar projects going up anytime soon. 
 I don't see them returning to their ATHs as quickly as any of the bluechips.

author: Firmest_Midget
body:
I also think there will be additional price declines, and plan to get more at those later times. If you're getting ENPH, be sure to also get SEDG. As I'm sure you're aware, they both manufacture solar DC/AC inverters, but they take different approaches to the tech, and actually occupy different niches within the solar world. Combined, these two make up 80% of the North American solar market - which is still expected to grow by 20% this year, despite the pandemic.  

My company brokers wind and solar Power Purchase Agreements. Our clients want renewable power, and we make it happen for them, sending out RFPs to developers and getting their project bids. We get a fee from our clients for brokering these projects. We also finance solar projects ourselves so that we own the power - this is a steady source of revenue for the life of the solar system. We closed ~$270mil of on-site solar deals in the last month. All of our clients have affirmed that they still wish to proceed with their projects, and there is no percepitble drop in interest in this sector. All systems are green!

author: -Brodysseus
body:
Just based off the past 5 year performance and their holdings I'd go for just SPY over SDY, 3.6 div yield is nice but SDY is up 3% past 5 years compared to SPY's 27% plus the 2.33 div yield. 

SEDG and ENPH are individual energy stocks, and looks like PBD is a energy portfolio so buying all three would kinda be redundant

VGT is a solid technology ETF too since you didn't mention any

author: Good_Sportsman
body:
If you really wanted to buy just stick to solid companies or etfs. GOOGL, AAPL, MSFT, FB, etc and etfs lik voo, spy, qqq or xlk(?)are going to do fine. 

AMZN, DG are solid bets to weather the storm but arent down a ton compared to others.

Anything thats a necessity or provides bargains will be fine PG, KO, PEP, HD, WMT, etc

Medical is probably okay tho I'd stick with solid companies not speculative unless you can tolarate risk but BMY, JNJ, ABBV, etc should be fine.

Defense never goes away HON, LMT, RNT, etc

Can play the "game is rigged" card and go with kinda scumbags JPM, BLK, etc

Utilities AWK, AQN, D, SO, WEC etc just watch for what kind of exposure you want i.e. oil, coal, nat gas folk have different feels on em.

Renewables its eventually the future but caution as the sector is getting fucked by cheap oil, the pandemic, and a loss of subsidies. A dem in the white house would prob be needed to get the subsidies back. But SEDG, NEE, VSLR, ENPH, etc are decent.

There's a bunch of other good buys for good reasons but this should be a good start for ya.

Also and it should be obvious, I am not a financial advisor nor should anything I say be taken as anything other than friendly scuttlebutt.

Tickers are from memory so hopefully I got em right.r

Edit: typos
